author: 3xmd1559sporebraytondingo
content:
If a validator provides an attestation that only contains the source and target, then providing a second attestation later in the epoch that contains source, target and head will make the validator eligible for a slashing, since double voting violates the first Casper Commandment. [if not this is my present understanding]

Why is this the case?

author: 3xmd1559sporebraytondingo
content:
I'm wondering whether it's feasible to allow for "superset/backwards-compatible attestation updates" such that a validator could submit:

[1] source
[2] source + target
[3] source + target + head

For the same source and target (s.t. there are no conflicting submissions).
Of course the signatures will be different, but the content is such that [1] ⊆ [2] ⊆ [3].

author: 3xmd1559sporebraytondingo
content:
The head needs to be received within 1 slot in order for a validator to receive the corresponding reward.
It seems the source must be received within 5 slots, while the target can be received anytime during the epoch.

The principle benefit I see would be to allow message [1] to be sent early *without guaranteed forgoing of the head reward*, since the source is known at the start of the epoch. This would lead to greater network burden however.

author: 3xmd1559sporebraytondingo
content: My mental model might be far off: I'm imagining that if a validator knows it's attesting in slot 12 of an epoch, then it is able to construct a source-only attestation during earlier slots (and wait until slot 12 to propagate). Hence the question is whether making early propagation free in opportunity cost is possible.
